testCase.expectations:
- titles should look like these: "Programação","Ciência da Computação","Desenvolvimento Web","Engenharia de Software"
      - all titles and descriptions in Brazilian Portuguese

      
  - The main focus is the `title` field, no need to pay much attention to the `description` field
  - No level/joiner words like "basic", "intermediate", "advanced", "fundamentals", etc
  - No words like "course" in the title
  - Titles are always in Title Case

steps.conclusion: None

The suggestions are relevant and correctly formatted in Brazilian Portuguese, but for a vague input like "I want to code" the guidelines say to include the broad canonical title itself; the list omits "Programação", which was even highlighted in the expectations. All descriptions are exactly one sentence and titles follow Title Case with no level/joiner words.

Add the canonical "Programação" as one of the suggestions; optionally include closely related single-topic options such as "Algoritmos", "Estruturas de Dados" or "Banco de Dados" to give a clearer starting path for someone who wants to code, while keeping the same formatting rules.

steps.conclusion: None. The output follows the core rules: titles are in Title Case, in Spanish, single-topic, no levels, one-sentence descriptions, and includes “Derecho Chileno” as required.

Some titles are too general given the Chile-specific query (e.g., “Derecho Constitucional”, “Derecho Penal”, “Derecho Civil” could be Chile-focused); minor stylistic issue with capitalization of “Estado” in descriptions per Spain Spanish conventions.

Add more Chile-specific suggestions such as “Derecho Constitucional Chileno”, “Derecho Penal Chileno”, “Derecho Administrativo Chileno”, “Derecho Procesal Penal Chileno”, “Derecho Laboral Chileno”, “Derecho Tributario Chileno”; optionally increase the number of suggestions; refine descriptions to emphasize Chilean context and standardize capitalization (e.g., “Estado”).

testCase.expectations:

  - No words like "course" in the title
  - Titles are always in Title Case

steps.conclusion: None.

The TOEFL description uses a disputable superlative ('most recognized in the world'); otherwise, it follows all constraints: exactly two suggestions (TOEFL and Inglês), correct titles in Title Case, one-sentence descriptions, and Brazilian Portuguese.

Rephrase the TOEFL description to avoid unverifiable superlatives (e.g., 'amplamente reconhecido'); optionally emphasize relevance to exam sections and general skills while keeping exactly one sentence.

testCase.expectations:
- should include both "Física" and "Química"

      - may include broader or similar topics but it's not required
      - all titles and descriptions in Brazilian Portuguese

      
  - The main focus is the `title` field, no need to pay much attention to the `description` field
  - No level/joiner words like "basic", "intermediate", "advanced", "fundamentals", etc
  - No words like "course" in the title
  - Titles are always in Title Case

steps.conclusion: None. The response follows language, title, and description rules; includes both "Física" and "Química" separately; avoids a combined "Física e Química" title; and provides one-sentence descriptions in Brazilian Portuguese.

Very small stylistic issue: "Ciência Dos Materiais" would typically be written as "Ciência dos Materiais" in pt-BR; capitalization of the preposition "dos" in Title Case is debatable. Otherwise, titles look like real courses and comply with constraints.

Could include a few more relevant, single-topic suggestions to broaden options (e.g., "Termodinâmica", "Eletromagnetismo", "Mecânica Quântica", "Química Orgânica", "Química Analítica"). Optionally adjust casing to "Ciência dos Materiais" for more natural pt-BR styling while maintaining Title Case intent.
